SEARCH
Package algorithms.heapsAndPQs

Class Heap

java.lang.Object
algorithms.heapsAndPQs.Heap
public class Heap extends Object
Class contains a Fibonacci heap, that is, a loose collection of trees based upon binomial heaps, hence satisfying the minimum heap property: object.child.key .geq. object.key. With a Fibonacci heap, the minimum key of the entire heap is always at the top of one of the trees. Fibonacci heap potential = t + 2m where t = number of trees m = number of marked nodes. (marked when node has been recently made a child of another node and .geq. 1 of it's own children have been cut. root nodes are never marked.) 
 Runtime complexity:

    Find-minimum is O(1) amortized time because there is always an instance
 reference to it.

    Insert, decrease key work in constant amortized time, O(1).

    Delete and delete minimum work in O(log n) amortized time.

    Extract-min and delete should be used sparingly for this structure to be
 best utilized and are usually implemented as O(log_2 N).

 This was implemented following pseudo-code from
 "Introduction to Algorithms", by Cormen, Leiserson, Rivest, and Stein
 on the Fibonacci Heap.
Author:
nichole

    • decreaseKey

      public void decreaseKey(HeapNode x, long decreaseToThisKey)
      decrease key for node x. Note that it is the responsibility of the invoker to assert that x is currently in the heap. If x is not in the heap, it gets added to it and then the state of the heap is corrupted. runtime is O(1)
      Parameters:
      x -
      decreaseToThisKey -
